text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today 
I'm taking a little break from cooking to talk

about an ingredient that I use all the time in my 
recipes and it's a pantry staple in Thai cuisine

and that is tamarind now I get a lot of questions 
about tamarind so hopefully this video will help

answer them all so I'm gonna cover what tamarind 
is how to buy it how to use it and how to store

it so let's get started all right first what is 
tamarind so cameron is actually a fruit okay and

a lot of people even people who cook with tamarind 
all the time have never actually seen the fruit

because unless you live in Thailand or one of 
those countries where tamarind is indigenous it's

very hard to find fresh tamarind pot so I finally 
found it the other day which is the reason why

I'm doing this video and this is what it looks 
like the shell is hard and the way you open it

is you just break it apart and you pray that the 
inside is good and you pull it out and inside I

know it's not the most appetizing looking thing 
but this is what it looks like and they're all

these veins that makes it look a little bit like 
an alien there we go now this is actually not the

kind of hammering that we cook with because this 
one is sweet and the one that we cook with looks

exactly like this except it's sour so if you ever 
come across sweet tamarind you want to eat it I'll

show you you want to remove the veins and then 
you just sort of suck the flesh off of the seat

because there are hard seats inside and that's 
it I see it comes out I apologize we're spitting

on camera but there you go that is Tamron super 
delicious the flesh is sticky kind of like dates

very similar to dates it's not as mushy Estate's 
sweetness will vary this one is very sweet but

just a tiny hint of sour and it ranges from this 
to very very sour and the one that's very sour

is the one that we cook with so let's take a look 
at that when it comes to cooking with Tamron this

is the product that you see me use all the time 
and I don't show you the package often enough

but this is what it looks like and by the way in 
my recipes I always call this tamarind juice and

this is basically the flesh of the tamarind so 
the brown flesh that you saw me eat diluted with

water so that it's now spoon herbal and easily 
mix into your cooking the label will usually

call it Tamron concentrate or tamarind paste 
which drives me crazy because it is neither a

paste like this does not qualify us who pays for 
me nor a concentrates because clearly they mix

this through the water so I don't know what that 
anyway that's the way it is this one is called

tamarind paste concentrate which makes even less 
sense sometimes it comes in a glass jar like this

this one is called tamarind paste they're both the 
same however beware of products that are called

tamarind sauce if it's a tamarind sauce check the 
ingredients because sometimes it's like a Ready

Mix sauce for another dish the ingredients should 
only say Terran and water and maybe a preservative

another question that I get a lot is what brand 
should you go with in my experience it doesn't

matter I haven't used yet a bad brand now brands 
will vary in acidity how sour the tamarind is but

even within the same brand different batches it's 
not gonna have the same level of acidity so to me

it's just you know get whatever you have having 
said that if I get a choice I always choose ones

that are from Thailand because I know that if 
Thai people make it they're making it for the

purpose that I needed products of Vietnam work 
just as well that I found products of India

however is an entirely different ingredient okay 
you see sometimes tamarind concentrate but it's a

product of India and then the container will look 
a little different that is a true concentrate it's

very thick very sticky very sour and it's almost 
black and you can't use that in the same way that

I use in my recipes I haven't tested it myself 
because I can't find it in my local stores but

people have told me that if you diluted with water 
you can use it as a substitute for this however I

haven't personally tested it so if you've tried it 
let me know if you've had success with it alright

so if you can't find the liquid which is what my 
recipe is always call for there's also this and

this is it'll say Tamron just Tamron does there 
were no other description this is tamarind pulp

so it's the brown thing that I was eating earlier 
and they've just compacted it into this block

there are no seeds in here it'll say without seeds 
but the membrane around the seats are in here so

you'll need to strain it out so what you do with 
this is you just take out a bunch and then you

just put it in a bowl so you just break it up 
a little bit and this is completely edible by

the way so you could taste it in fact that is very 
sour its it's still tasty holy mother okay now I'm

gonna put some hot water and just pour just until 
it's submerged and I'm just gonna let it sit that

way until the flesh will sort of loosen up and 
then we can really squeeze it out now I should

tell you that this form of tamarind is actually 
the form that most Thai people use in Thailand

this liquid stuff is like high-tech stuff that is 
new and the grocery store most people in Thailand

even today are making tamarind juice from the 
flesh that's what I grew up using I only started

using this when I came to Canada it's convenient 
though I'm kind of spoiled now so it's been about

15 minutes and the water is now cool enough to 
handle and the flesh is also loosened up a bit

so now I'm going to basically juice it and this 
is why I call it tamarind juice even though it's

not technically juice but you know it's what 
I people called it and just try to get all the

flesh off of the membrane and the fibers that are 
in here uh I think I found a seed lies they said

no seeds the question I always get about this 
is well how much water do you need to add and

there is no correct amount I mean most people 
just randomly add enough water to cover it but

I would warn you against adding too much water 
because if this is really liquidy every time you

go to use tamarind you have to add a lot of extra 
water to your recipe as well so now this is very

thick it's fine but I'm actually gonna dilute it 
a little bit more because this will be difficult

to strain and to thin it out a little bit and when 
you home make tamarin I find it's always a little

more runny than the commercially made one I could 
spend a little more time getting every last bit of

flesh but I'll just show you what to do from this 
point on you're gonna strain it and yes ideally

your sieve would be a little bigger than this so 
I have to say that this is a little thicker than

most home cooks will make it because it's quite a 
bit of work to strain this out but what I'm trying

to do here is to get it as close as possible to 
the stuff that you can buy in the jar cuz you know

that's my recipes are based on that so I wanted to 
show you how you can make sort of a similar thing

at home so now that you've got your tamron how 
to store it now this product is shelf stable but

as soon as you open it you have to put it in the 
fridge and it'll last at least one month I have

yet to have one of these go bad on me because it's 
acidic right so it lasts quite a while the stuff

that you make yourself though this won't last as 
long because you know your hands get in there and

you know get very intimate with it if you want you 
can cook it and it will last longer because you've

killed the bacteria that you've introduced from 
your hands if you're not sure how long you know

when you're gonna use it you can always put it 
in the freezer and if you're gonna freeze them

I recommend freezing them in small portions 
like little ice cubes so that it's easier for

you to just take a little bit to use this stuff 
the tamarind pulp when you buy it it'll be sold

outside so don't look for this in the fridge and 
you can keep it in your cupboard for two years

according to the expiration date on here once you 
open it though I put it in the fridge okay and

that will last a very long time again I've yet 
to see one of these go bad on me cuz it's very

sour finally how to use Tamron Tamron can used in 
absolutely any kind of dish soup salad curry stir

fries dip we use it in everything now as many 
of you know Thai food is all about balancing

sweet salty and sour so tamarind is one our main 
sour ingredients the other one being lime however

unlike lime tamarin can be cooked for a long time 
and the flavor won't deteriorate and it's also

not as sharp as lime okay it's it's always got a 
note of sweetness to it the acidity is more gentle

so a lot of times we use it in combination with 
lime in order to sort of have a bit of a balance

of sharp and rounded acidity so it's a really 
interesting ingredients if you've ever used it

in outside of Thai cuisine if your cuisine uses 
tamarin in a different way please let me know I'd

love to know what you guys use it for so I hope 
you learn something new and interesting today and

I hope that if you had questions about tamarind 
they have been answered if not if I miss anything

send me your questions on Facebook or through 
the contact form on my website or Twitter and

I'll be happy to answer them and I will see 
you next time for your next delicious time
you
